item.title: MySQL Replication: Wrap-up
item.description: After a couple of weeks, my MySQL replication series has come to a close.

item.title: MySQL Replication: Slave Performance
item.description: There’s a few final configuration options that may help the performance of your slave MySQL servers.

item.title: MySQL Replication: Upgrading the MySQL server
item.description: If you want to make a DBA nervous, just let them know that they need to upgrade MySQL servers that are replicating in a production environment.

item.title: MySQL Replication: Across an external network
item.description: While many people might find replicating over an external network to be an odd concept, it does have some uses.

item.title: MySQL Replication: Breakdown
item.description: On some occasions, MySQL replication can break down if an statement comes from the master that makes no sense to the slave.

item.title: MySQL Replication: Delayed Slaves
item.description: In a perfect world, slaves will contain the same data as the master at all times.

item.title: MySQL Replication: Horizontal Data Partitioning
item.description: If you have a master with multiple slaves, you can get some performance and save money on hardware by splitting data horizontally among your servers.

item.title: MySQL Replication: Backups & Data Integrity
item.description: An often overlooked benefit of MySQL replication is the ability to make reliable backups without affecting the integrity of the MySQL data.

item.title: MySQL Replication: Redundancy
item.description: Although performance is a much larger benefit of replication, it provides some redundancy for your application as well.

item.title: MySQL Replication: Performance
item.description: MySQL replication can increase performance by allowing developers to spread queries over two servers.

item.title: MySQL Replication: A series of posts
item.description: One of the topics I receive the most questions about is MySQL replication.

item.title: Seven Step MySQL Replication
item.description: MySQL replication may sound complicated, but it can be done easily.

item.title: mysqldump: Got packet bigger than â€˜max_allowed_packetâ€™ bytes
item.description: When you dump table data from MySQL, you may end up pulling a large chunk of data and it may exceed the MySQL client’s max_allowed_packet variable.
